metadata.title: Therapeutic Exercise  Strength Training –Kettlebells
description: Kettlebells are hand weights with U-shaped  handles that enable them to be swung?A few cohort studies have shown that therapeutic swing-training  exercises are effective for improving functional strength and power.(1,2,3,4) However, evidence is lacking that kettlebells are more effective than strength or power training exercises using other handheld or loading devices(5)

A potential advantage of kettlebell swing training is that joint actions can simulate daily activities. For example, kettlebell swings utilizing the hip-hinge  technique may elicit lower-limb muscle activation patterns similar to running(6)
reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified Indications for Procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Does the patient’s status involve special considerations? –Review any special considerations in addition to those listed above

indications for procedure: Indicated for patients undergoing sports rehabilitation therapy
Indicated for patients toimprove strength, dynamic flexibility, and power fordaily activities(2,3,4)
Kettlebell swing-training  also serves as an alternative rehabilitation exercise to improve muscle endurance(1)

contraindications precautions to examina: Does the patient’s status involve special considerations? –Review any special considerations in addition to those listed above

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Describe the patient’s current musculoskeletal injuries. How did these injuries occur?

course of treatment.medical management: Patient should be cleared medically prior to participating in therapeutic kettlebell exercises. Medical management will vary based on history and reason for referral
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective?Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Determine any aggravating or easing factors specific to this patient
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient had any recent injuries or dysfunction?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient plan on returning to work? What specific movements does work require? Does the patient participate in any competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient require assistance with ADLs at home? Does the patient have any limitations in functional mobility? Does the patient use any adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight.Calculate BMI. Is weight loss or a gain in muscle mass one of the training goals?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Provide patient with proper education and measurements when using any type of adaptive equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance statically and dynamically; use the Tinetti Balance Scale or the Berg Balance Scale for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess patient’s functional mobility using the Functional Independence Measure (FIM) or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess patient’s gait for deviations. Note the gait quality and determine any abnormalities in gait. The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used for standardized testing of safety with ambulationAssess bilateral upper and lower extremity joint function and mobility. Establish proper form and stability in the joints to ensure safe training when performing exercises using the kettlebell
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform manual muscle testing (MMT) and assess scores for the upper and lower extremities
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess the patient’s posture during the exercises and note any deviations in alignment
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Use a goniometer to measure upper and lower extremity ROM. Sufficient ROM and flexibility are important when performing kettlebell swing exercises to ensure proper exercise performance and to minimize risk of injuryAssess ADLs using the Barthel index

other: Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Due to the explosive nature and dynamics of performing kettlebell exercises, extra precaution should be taken in order to minimize risk of injuries

treatment summary: Ensure that the kettlebell training program is consistent with guidelines for resistance training programs concerning the individualized type, intensity, duration, and mode of training(7)

Authors of a cohort study in the United States tested the strengthening benefit of a kettlebell training program using the barbell bench press, back extension test, and clean-and-jerk  test. Thirty-seven  subjectswere randomized to an experimental group (n=23, mean age 40.9 years) or a control group (n=14, 39.6 years).After 10 weeks (2 days/week) of kettlebell training, the experimental group showed significantly (P<0.05) improved strength in the barbell bench press. In contrast,their mean strength in the back extension and clean-and-jerk  tests failed to reach statistical significance.(1) This is an example of how the benefit of kettlebell swing-training  (i.e., a specific mode of strength training)has not been shown in commonly used strength tests
A practice exemplar describes how kettlebell training can be incorporated into a lower extremity sports rehabilitation program(2)

Kettlebell exercises for the rotator cuff group can emphasize specific muscles. For example, authors of a cross-sectional EMG study (n=10 volunteers) in the United States compared the muscle activation patterns in the rotator cuff and scapular musculature during five commonlyutilized kettlebell exercises. Significant (P < 0.05) EMG differences between the exercises were observed for all target muscles except the infraspinatus(3)

Authors of a cross-sectional  cohort study (n=19 recreationallyactive men) in Taiwan measured the EMG responses of the quadriceps, hamstrings, tibialis anterior, and gastrocnemius lateralis and medialis during loaded and unloaded squat and  lunge exercises. In the squat, significantly (P<0.05) less EMG activation was found in the semitendinosus and tibialis anterior for loading with kettlebells compared to loading with a barbell, dumbbell, or vest of the same weight(4)

Authors of a controlled cohort study of 20 moderatelytrained subjects (12 men and 8 women) in Australia found thatusing kettlebell hip swings for a warm-up  did not enhance 20-meter  sprint performanceas compared to no warm-up(6)

Controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of kettlebell swing-training  as compared to other modes of strength training(5) See Description, Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain in shoulders, neck, and low backDecrease musculoskeletal painTherapeutic exercises _ Kettlebell exercises such as swings, suitcase carry, and overhead pressIncrease intensity and repetitions of exercises as necessaryProvide exercises at home that decrease patient’s pain symptoms Decreased muscular strength and enduranceImprove muscle strength and enduranceTherapeutic exercises _ Can utilize exercises with the kettlebell such as the one-leg deadlift, kettlebell swings, squat and pressIncrease intensity and repetitions of exercises as necessaryProvide exercises at home to improve muscular strength and endurance .

increased strength and endurance: MMT, dynamometer, 1-repetition  max, 6MWT, Bruce protocol, Borg RPE

maintenance or prevention: Therapist can provide a home exercise program to allow patients to continue to train on their own once therapy sessions are complete
Patients can purchase their own kettlebell and perform exercises independently under the supervision of a therapist or kettlebell trainer
patient education: In order to reduce risk of injury, patients should be educated on proper form and technique for kettlebell exercises Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
